title: From Imaging Conductivity to Imaging Electron Density
content: A relatively new imaging technique for the scanning transmission electron microscope (STEM) has been developed and the microscopy community is in the process of delineating its uses for the examination of the electronic properties of the materials under examination. This imaging technique is closely related to electron-beam-induced current (EBIC) imaging that has been employed in scanning electron microscopes (SEMs) for many years. With this technique sample currents are monitored as a function of the position of a scanning e-beam to reveal spatially resolved information about charge carriers in the sample. In a STEM the image contrast formation is based on the emission of secondary electrons (SEs) from the sample, leading to the terminology ‘SEEBIC imaging’ [1].
